abstract: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters packed the streets of the capital, rejecting President Abdelaziz Bouteflika’s offer not to seek a fifth term.

headline: Attack on Government Minister Rattles New Zealand’s Friendly Politics
abstract: The attack on the minister for climate change stunned a country where only the prime minister has security and constituents don’t shy from approaching their leaders.

headline: Lilly Singh, a YouTube Star, Will Host a Late-Night Show on NBC
abstract: The half-hour show will premiere in September and make her the only woman with a late-night show on one of the so-called Big Four broadcast networks, a statement said.

headline: James Gunn Is Hired Back to Helm ‘Guardians of the Galaxy 3’
abstract: Disney had fired the filmmaker in July after offensive jokes he wrote on Twitter several years ago resurfaced. The dismissal prompted an outcry from the film franchise’s cast and fans.

headline: Vietnam’s Communist Party Ousts Historian Who Criticized Its China Policy
abstract: Tran Duc Anh Son has argued that Vietnam should take a tougher line against China’s territorial claims in the South China Sea, a sensitive matter for the government.

headline: New Zealand Muslims Await Word From Mosque Attacks: ‘Everybody Knew Each Other’
abstract: In a closely knit community of about 50,000, phones were ringing unanswered late Friday, and reassurance was hard to come by.

headline: In Ethiopia, a Day of Mourning With Empty Coffins for Plane Crash Victims
abstract: Families have no bodies to bury because the 157 victims died in a fiery explosion when Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 hurtled to the ground near Addis Ababa.

headline: China’s Premier Acknowledges Economic Slowdown, Promising Tax Cuts
abstract: Responding to concerns raised by the United States and its allies, the premier also denied Beijing asks Chinese companies to engage in overseas spying.

headline: Facebook’s Daylong Malfunction Is a Reminder of the Internet’s Fragility
abstract: The incident, which also affected WhatsApp and Instagram, was caused by a small mistake that led to big problems.

headline: As Mark Zuckerberg Tightens Grip on Facebook, 2 Top Deputies Leave
abstract: Chris Cox, who is one of the social network’s highest ranking executives, and Chris Daniels, head of WhatsApp, are leaving Facebook.

headline: Professor Sings at Indonesia Rally. He Faces 4 Years in Jail for Defaming Army.
abstract: Rights groups say there is an “alarming” crackdown on speech in Indonesia, with the authorities using a criminal defamation law against citizens who protest policies or complain about companies.

headline: Explosion at China Chemical Plant Kills 64; Employees Detained
abstract: An undisclosed number of factory personnel were held after the blast, which raised fears that toxic substances could spread.

headline: Mueller Speculation on TV Gives Way to Hard News. Then It’s Back to Speculation.
abstract: Anchors posed questions for hours on Friday while waiting for the special counsel’s report to drop. When it did, there were few answers.

headline: Levi’s, Whose Jeans Are a Rugged Symbol of Americana, Prepares to Go Public
abstract: The maker of denim and Dockers will start trading on Thursday, a milestone for a 165-year-old company that has experienced a resurgence in the past decade.

headline: Explosion Rocks Industrial Zone in Eastern China, Killing 47
abstract: The blast occurred at a chemical plant, and videos online showed people who appeared to have been cut by glass and other debris.

headline: Theresa May’s Message to Britain at a Perilous Moment: It’s Parliament’s Fault
abstract: In an address to the nation Wednesday night, the prime minister lashed out, blaming squabbling lawmakers for the Brexit paralysis. They did not react well.

headline: New Zealand Took 6 Days to Plan New Gun Laws. Here’s How Other Countries Reacted to Shootings.
abstract: New Zealand’s prime minister made the announcement less than a week after the Christchurch massacre. Mass shootings have also had a mobilizing effect in Australia, Britain, Canada and Germany.

headline: Bus Fire in China Kills Dozens of People
abstract: The long-distance coach bus was taking tourists to Mao Zedong’s hometown when the fire erupted, according to Chinese state media. At least 26 people were killed.

headline: Mozambique, Battered by Cyclone, Takes Stock: ‘It’s All Rotten’
abstract: As the storm waters began to recede, people who had very little before the storm found that they now have even less.

headline: New Zealand to Ban Military-Style Semiautomatic Guns, Jacinda Ardern Says
abstract: The announcement on Thursday from New Zealand’s prime minister came less than a week after a massacre at two mosques in Christchurch.

headline: ‘So Heartbreaking’: Funerals Begin for New Zealand Attack Victims
abstract: As the first six victims of the Christchurch mosque shootings were laid to rest, some affected families were still waiting to learn the fate of their loved ones.

headline: Scores of Holiday Revelers Killed as Overloaded Ferry Sinks in Iraq
abstract: The vessel, carrying Iraqis celebrating the Kurdish New Year, sank in the Tigris River near Mosul, killing at least 94 people.

headline: Trump Declares ISIS ‘100%’ Defeated in Syria. ‘100% Not True,’ Ground Reports Say.
abstract: The Pentagon scrambled to respond to President Trump’s remarks about how much land has been taken from the Islamic State.

headline: For U.K.’s Labour, Anti-Semitism and Corbyn Are as Divisive as Brexit
abstract: As another party lawmaker left for an independent grouping, leaders struggled to combat charges that Labour is “institutionally anti-Semitic.”

headline: Brexit Live Updates: Parliament Votes to Postpone Britain’s E.U. Departure
abstract: Unable to agree among themselves on Brexit terms, British lawmakers directed the government to ask the European Union to delay the March 29 deadline.

headline: Why Paying Bribes to Get Your Child Into College Is a Crime
abstract: The “right of honest services” turns paying a university employee to admit an unqualified student into a federal crime because it violates honest services owed to the school.

headline: Merkel Staying Out of Merger Talks Between Germany’s Top Banks
abstract: A potential merger between Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank is a private economic affair and the government should stay out of it, Chancellor Angela Merkel said.

headline: Trade Fight With China Enters Overtime, With Tariffs a Costly Sticking Point
abstract: Although much remains unsettled before an April goal, one thing is clear: The Trump administration wants to hold the threat of tariffs over Beijing.

headline: How Executives Vote With Their Wallets
abstract: A Harvard study found that executives donate more heavily to Republicans. But the gap is surprising.

headline: Bombed by ISIS, an Afghan Wrestling Club Is Back: ‘They Can’t Stop Us’
abstract: The wrestlers of the Maiwand club have taken their revenge. Their gym is bigger, better and busier than it was before.

headline: Exiled Cambodian Opposition Leaders Are Indicted as Prime Minister Tightens Grip
abstract: Warrants accused them of incitement to commit a felony and plotting treason, charges they say are baseless and proof of Hun Sen’s strangling of dissent.

headline: A.I. Is Flying Drones (Very, Very Slowly)
abstract: Artificial intelligence has bested top players in chess, Go and even StarCraft. But can it fly a drone faster than a pro racer? More than $1 million is on the line to find out.

headline: For PG&E Board Candidate, ‘Job One Is to Restore the Public Trust’
abstract: Phil Angelides, one of 13 people on a slate nominated by a hedge fund, discussed what went wrong at the California utility and how it can be revived.

headline: Ex- Hong Kong Official Gets Lighter Sentence in Bribery Case
abstract: Patrick Ho, who was convicted in a bribery case connected to a Chinese oil company, received a lenient sentence partly because of good works in custody.

headline: Warnings of a Dark Side to A.I. in Health Care
abstract: Machine-learning systems could be a boon to medicine. But they also can be hacked to mislead, researchers are discovering.

headline: Boeing 737 Max Hit Trouble Right Away, Pilot’s Tense Radio Messages Show
abstract: “Break break, request back to home,” the captain of the ill-fated Ethiopian Airlines flight radioed air traffic controllers minutes after taking off.

headline: After 2 Crashes of New Boeing Jet, Pilot Training Now a Focus
abstract: When the 737 Max was introduced, Boeing and regulators agreed that pilots who had flown an earlier model didn’t need additional simulator training.

headline: Hamas Crackdown on Gaza Protests Instills Fear
abstract: When protests erupted across Gaza to protest tax increases and demand better living conditions, Hamas responded by beating demonstrators and detaining 1,000 people.

headline: Algeria Army Chief Opens Path to End of Bouteflika’s Rule
abstract: A top power broker expressed support for what he called the “legitimate demands” of protesters who want President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to step down.

headline: ‘In Afghanistan, We Laugh Differently’
abstract: For a handful of teenage girls, robotics offered a reprieve from their violent, patriarchal country. Now they are back home, with the Taliban poised to gain power.

headline: Ahead of Israel’s Election, Gantz’s Meme-Inspiring Missteps Embolden Netanyahu
abstract: Nothing played out as expected this past week, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s vulnerability seemed to recede a bit as his challenger faltered.

headline: New Zealand’s Gun Laws Draw Scrutiny After Mosque Shootings
abstract: The country’s gun culture is deeply ingrained. Now, after 49 people were gunned down at two mosques, lawmakers could consider making guns less easy to obtain.

headline: Is Poland Spring Water Really From a Spring? ‘Not One Drop,’ Says a Lawsuit
abstract: Nestlé Waters says the claims against its brand are “meritless.” The case has moved forward in Connecticut.

headline: Brunei to Punish Adultery and Gay Sex With Death by Stoning
abstract: Statutes allowing stoning and amputation will go into effect in the sultanate beginning on April 3. That has set off an outcry from human rights groups.

headline: Fox News, After Rebuking Jeanine Pirro, Faces Another Uproar Over Tucker Carlson
abstract: The network reproached Ms. Pirro, a star host, for suggesting that a Muslim congresswoman’s religious beliefs were anti-American. Tucker Carlson, another Fox host, is also under fire.

headline: After India Loses Dogfight to Pakistan, Questions Arise About Its ‘Vintage’ Military
abstract: As America strengthens its alliance with India to help counter China, critics say its military faces serious challenges, from the age of its hardware to the size of its budget.

headline: Microsoft’s Bing Back Online in China After Apparent Blockage
abstract: Users in parts of China were unable to access Bing on Wednesday and Thursday, and it remains unclear what led to the shutdown.

headline: Russian Hackers Targeted European Research Groups, Microsoft Says
abstract: The attacks, which come ahead of elections in May, reflect the spread of a broad online campaign linked to Moscow to disrupt its political opponents.

headline: Envoys Denounce Venezuela’s Maduro and Urge Him to Cede Power
abstract: Thirteen nations announced on Friday that they would not recognize the legitimacy of the new term of President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: Who’s Really Getting Ripped Off by $35 Sage?
abstract: Demand for the new ‘it shrub’ is pushing up prices — and irritating some members of America's indigenous communities.

headline: Protesting ‘Slave Law,’ Thousands Take to Streets in Hungary
abstract: A law compelling people to work hundreds of hours of overtime without full or immediate compensation has created a new, and diverse, set of protesters.

headline: More Pet Insurance Policies Are Being Sold. But Are They Worth the Cost?
abstract: Consumer advocates say pet owners should bring a healthy skepticism when shopping for insurance.

headline: Matteo Salvini Likes Nutella and Kittens. It’s All Part of a Social Media Strategy.
abstract: The online feed of Italy’s most powerful politician is not about product placement, but a studied way to sell his common-man brand in an anti-elite era.

headline: Hackers Leak Details of German Lawmakers, Except Those on Far Right
abstract: Twitter has shut down an account that had been posting personal data for weeks. Only the Alternative for Germany party appeared to be unscathed.

headline: U.S. Renews China Travel Warning, Citing Risk of Arbitrary Detention
abstract: The State Department said that possible “exit bans” could trap Americans in China.

headline: Belgium Bans Religious Slaughtering Practices, Drawing Praise and Protest
abstract: Animal rights groups praised the new law banning halal and kosher practices, but Muslims and Jews see it as part of a right-wing nationalist agenda.

headline: Trump Has Promised to Bring Jobs Back. His Tariffs Threaten to Send Them Away.
abstract: American factories complain that President Trump’s tariffs are hurting profits in the industrial heartland.

headline: Devices That Will Invade Your Life in 2019 (and What’s Overhyped)
abstract: A.I. that responds to your voice. Next-generation wireless networks. If this year’s biggest consumer technology trends have a familiar ring, there’s a reason for that.

headline: Offered Free Tickets for ‘Schindler’s List,’ Germany’s Far Right Sees a Provocation
abstract: A German movie theater wanted to start a discussion about history and the Holocaust, but the AfD called the offer a “tasteless instrumentalization.”

headline: Their Approach to Career Changes? Find a Niche, and Fill It
abstract: People change gears for all sorts of reasons — they have no other option or they find something they love more. The successful ones are comfortable with the risk.

headline: China Pours $218 Billion Into the Economy as Growth Slows
abstract: The Chinese central bank’s move is intended to send a signal that Beijing is ready to stem a slowdown that has darkened the global outlook.

headline: Rwanda Cracks Down on Skin Bleaching Agents by Seizing Cosmetics
abstract: Pointing to the chemicals’ harmful health effects, the country has begun enforcing its ban on bleaching agents, especially hydroquinone and mercury.

headline: Saudi Woman Who Fled Family Granted Asylum in Canada
abstract: Rahaf Mohammed Alqunun, 18, had rallied support from a Bangkok hotel room to avoid being deported, saying she feared that her relatives might kill her.

headline: The Exclusive That Wasn’t? Publication Retracts Moonves Interview
abstract: Agenda, a news service owned by The Financial Times, published an interview with someone claiming to be Mr. Moonves shortly after he was fired as chief executive of CBS.

headline: Jakiw Palij, Former Nazi Guard Deported After Decades in U.S., Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Palij had lived for decades in Queens. Although ordered deported in 2004, no country agreed to take him for 14 years.

headline: $40 Million Claim Against Bollywood-Loving Sheikh Dismissed by British Court
abstract: The sheikh, a cousin of the king of Bahrain, had been accused of breaking a contract to pay $1.5 million for each of 26 meetings with movie stars.

headline: Year of Free Credit Report Monitoring Is Ending. Here’s What to Do Now.
abstract: The free service started after Equifax’s huge breach in 2017. Consumer advocates suggest placing a security freeze — not a lock — on credit files.

headline: A South Korean Ex-Chief Justice Faces Case-Rigging Accusations
abstract: The former Supreme Court chief justice is accused of conspiring with the government to manipulate its ruling on Japanese companies said to have used forced labor in wartime.

headline: Japan’s Olympics Chief Faces Corruption Charges in France
abstract: The accusations against Tsunekazu Takeda relate to Tokyo’s winning bid to host the 2020 Games — the latest in a string of corruption cases in Olympic bidding.

headline: It’s Official: The Trump Tax Cuts Didn’t Pay for Themselves in Year One
abstract: Federal tax revenues declined in 2018 while economic growth accelerated, undercutting the Trump administration’s insistence that the $1.5 trillion tax package would pay for itself.

headline: U.S.-North Korea Summit Looks Imminent, South Korean Leader Says
abstract: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea said Kim Jong-un’s visit to China this week indicated that the North Korean leader would soon have a second meeting with President Trump.

headline: 52 Places to Go: How Perth and Northern Rivers Made the List
abstract: This week’s Australia Letter wants to get away from it all, but will settle for explaining The New York Times’s annual travel guide.

headline: Guatemala’s Experiment in Fighting Corruption Is Under Attack
abstract: An international panel brought charges against business leaders and politicians. Now it has focused on President Jimmy Morales. He wants to shut it down.

headline: Carlos Ghosn Emerges to Say He Was ‘Wrongly Accused and Unfairly Detained’
abstract: Mr. Ghosn, the ousted Nissan chief, made his first public appearance since his November arrest to defend himself in a Tokyo court against charges of financial wrongdoing.

headline: Migrants’ Despair Is Growing at U.S. Border. So Are Smugglers’ Profits.
abstract: Only a handful of asylum seekers are let across the border each day. Many are now weighing the risks of hiring “polleros” to sneak them in.

headline: Fleeing Saudi Woman, Facing Deportation, Is Allowed to Remain in Thailand
abstract: Rahaf Mohammed Alqunun, 18, said she feared that she would be killed if she were sent back to her family. She was allowed to leave a Bangkok airport with United Nations officials.

headline: Fed Ready to Pause on Interest Rate Increases
abstract: Fed minutes and comments by officials signal that the central bank will not raise rates at its next meeting, in January, and is unlikely to do so at the following meeting, in March.

headline: CES 2019: It’s the Year of Virtual Assistants and 5G
abstract: A visual tour of the world’s most important tech conference offers a window into the year’s trends, including next-generation wireless networks and the invasion of A.I.

headline: In Bosnia, a Father’s Grief Swells Into an Antigovernment Movement
abstract: The case of David Dragicevic, who was found dead in March, has become a rallying point for people disaffected with the Bosnian Serb politician Milorad Dodik.

headline: Legal Battle Between Sumner Redstone and Former Girlfriend Is Settled
abstract: Manuela Herzer will pay back $3.25 million that Mr. Redstone had given her in gifts and money over the years. The long-running dispute had challenged Mr. Redstone’s mental capacity.

headline: Congo Presidential Election Results Delayed
abstract: People in the Democratic Republic of Congo had been told they would learn who their new leader was on Wednesday night. The hour passed with no word.

headline: 40 Million Watched Trump’s Prime-Time Address on TV
abstract: Critics had questioned why networks agreed to air the president. While viewership was robust, it fell short of last year’s State of the Union address.

headline: You Know Your Diamond’s Cut and Carat. But Does It Have Ethical Origins?
abstract: Most buyers have no clue where their gems come from, and whether they are “blood diamonds.” Now, jewelers like Tiffany, hoping to attract millennials, are opening up their supply chains.

headline: Greek Militants Say They Bombed Media Offices to Protest ‘Capitalist’ Agenda
abstract: The Group of Popular Fighters claimed responsibility for the Dec. 17 attack, which caused serious damage but no injuries, accusing the media of supporting austerity programs.

headline: Far-Right, Anti-immigrant Vox Party Gains a Toehold in Spain
abstract: Riding anti-immigrant sentiment and opposition to separatism, the nationalist Vox party is emerging as a potential force in Spanish politics.

headline: Vogue Brazil Fashion Director Resigns Over Photos That Evoke Slavery Era
abstract: Donata Meirelles resigned after photos emerged from her 50th birthday that critics saw as allusion to race relations in the colonial era, when slavery was legal in Brazil.

headline: Students Skip School Across Europe to Demand Climate Action
abstract: In cities including Berlin, London and Paris, young protesters took to the streets to urge their leaders to combat climate change.

headline: New Zealand Fears Fraying Ties With China, Its Biggest Customer
abstract: The cancellation of a tourism initiative and the abrupt return of a Shanghai-bound Air New Zealand flight has many suspecting Chinese retaliation for a ban on the company Huawei.

headline: XPO Logistics Will Close Warehouse Where Some Pregnant Workers Miscarried
abstract: XPO said more than 400 employees would lose their jobs in April. The New York Times had reported on workers’ miscarriages and complaints of discrimination at the Memphis warehouse.

headline: India Proposes Chinese-Style Internet Censorship
abstract: The Modi government’s plan, which would require tech companies to automatically block a vast array of content, stifles free speech, critics said.

headline: In Mattis’s Shadow, Acting Pentagon Chief Tries to Reassure NATO Allies
abstract: Patrick Shanahan, the acting defense secretary, is not seen as a counterweight to President Trump’s distrust of alliances.

headline: Beware the Brexit Monster: Dutch Businesses Get a Furry Blue Warning
abstract: The Netherlands created the mascot as part of a set of business resources to avoid having “Brexit get in your way.”

headline: Sweden Investigates Its Ambassador to China After Report of Secret Talks to Free Publisher
abstract: The daughter of Gui Minhai, a Swedish bookseller detained in China, said the ambassador arranged a meeting with men who first offered to help, then cajoled and pressured her.

headline: Germany Is Wary of a Digital World (but Loves Its E-Toothbrushes)
abstract: Melissa Eddy, a Berlin reporter, explains how privacy laws have led to blurred Google Street View pictures, and why WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook are popular almost despite themselves.

headline: Huawei Was a Czech Favorite. Now? It’s a National Security Threat.
abstract: The Czech Republic has taken aggressive steps to limit the use of Huawei in 5G technology, setting off a fight being closely watched across Europe.

headline: The $89,000 Verdict Tearing Japan and South Korea Apart
abstract: Millions of Koreans were conscripted as forced labor during the Japanese occupation. Now Korean courts say that aging workers can sue Japanese companies for damages.

headline: It Started With a Jolt: How New York Became a Tech Town
abstract: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.

headline: When the Waiting Room Is Your Living Room
abstract: Start-ups are offering health care services like doctors, prescription drugs and wellness programs as fast and easy as hailing an Uber driver.

headline: The Police Were Called for Help. They Arrested Her Instead.
abstract: Over the past decade, laws in Western Australia have sent thousands of people to prison for unpaid fines. Aboriginal women are particularly vulnerable, and in the worst cases, have been arrested when they called for help.

headline: Pensions for Nazi Collaborators? Shocking if True (It’s a Big If)
abstract: Details about possible payments were found to be exaggerated, misleading or false, but despite the lack of hard evidence, Germany was put on the defensive.

headline: Kim Jong-un Arrives in Vietnam, for a Visit About More Than Trump
abstract: Political and historical symbolism will lie just below the surface as the North Korean leader visits Vietnam for a summit with President Trump.
